text: our next presenter is Michael warb he's

biologist at the University of Arizona
and he was part of a team of researchers
that had a very important paper

it was about the evolution of the swine
flu virus and what he basically found
was that it's been circulating
undetected in swine for perhaps up to a
decade Michael warie thanks

I thought first i' I'd put it in the
bigger context of the emergence of

to notice is for this H1 variant here
there's a nice human lineage the Spanish
Flu is on that there's a SW wine lineage
uh and there's a bird lineage and these
are the major players in the emergence
of of human

a picture from the paper that we

doesn't mean much to you all these lines

what we found here um and so coming from
British Columbia I like to use the Saro
as a as a teaching tool uh I actually
work in Arizona now so so it makes some
sense um with viruses uh they evolve so
quickly that you can actually see
Evolution happen uh not just on the time
frame of years but in this instance in
the time frame of weeks uh and this was
a bit of a surprise that with just a few
weeks of of sequences that were produced
as this pandemic was onf in we were able
able to calibrate the molecular clock um
so let me just use this analogy if you
wanted to find out how old your Saro was
uh you might not be able to do it uh uh
just by counting tree rings or something
um but if you had a photo from 1999 of
this cactus in your yard and you were
able to compare it to how much it had
grown in uh the 10 years since that time
you'd start to have a kind of grasp of
how quickly uh this thing grows and you
could make some estimates from the
different branches of the per cent
centimeter per year growth rate and that
could allow you to work back to when the
thing originated so we do the same thing
with viruses if you have a small
observation window like this you can
often make really robust inferences
about things much deeper in time okay so
so now as an analogy I just want to want
to show you uh an evolutionary tree that
you're probably more familiar with here
so we do the same sorts of things uh for
primates and if you did an evolutionary
tree of primates you would have uh a
human branch on the tree our most
closely uh related species are
chimpanzees and bonobos and then you
have more distantly related species here
um and you could place a date on the
most recent common ancestor of all
humans
and that might be around a 100,000 years
ago you could also ask what's the most
recent common ancestor of humans and
whatever is most closely related to them
and that's all the way back here around
5 million years
ago so for this swine or uh swine origin
uh flu pandemic we did exactly the same
thing so two questions what's the the
timing on that ancestor of the virus
once it jumped into humans um so when
did that jump take place and if you if
you go Gene by Gene and ask what's the

also ask for each gene when did that
break off from the rest of the sampled
Pig viruses okay so now we're back to
this and what you see for each gene is
the human sequences coales quite
recently in time uh but nowhere near the
March and April timeline that this thing
first emerged uh to um to our knowledge
um and for each of the genes the most
closely related sequences are from pigs
now now Peter mentioned that some of
them ultimately are of Aven origin and
some are of human
origin what you see when you go Gene by
Gene is that even for the ones that are
ultimately of Aven or human origin
they've traveled through pigs uh and in
each case we find that there's been a
timeline of about 10 years where this
virus has been in pigs but gone totally
unnoticed which says something about our
surveillance um and for the human
outbreak what you see is a timeline of
about uh somewhere around October to

this uh into this new swine origin
influenza
virus uh one other interesting detail
when you look Gene by
Gene um and and Peter showed a nice

these are actual physically separated uh
chromosomes you can actually place a
date for each one of those as to when it
got into humans um when you do that and
you line it up against the answer you
get if you take all of the genes
together you get a little bit of a
discrepancy and this discrepancy it
turns out you you get an earlier date
with each gene than you do with the
entire
genome um and we think what's going on
there is once this virus jumped into
humans it actually started evolving at a
more rapid pace and it looks like it
goes at about 1.5 times the rate that it
evolves in pigs uh and there are some
interesting reasons why that might be if

change these Gene by Gene estimates
actually start to overlap the entire

converge on this

into the very first few weeks uh of

and
spreading um so aside from the actual
findings I just want to spend a couple
of moments talking about how this
happened so uh when these sequences
first came out they were published uh by
places like ncbi and
GIS and what was great about this
situation was that information was made
publicly available by pretty much all
the parties in real time uh and so as
soon as sequences were available I
started analyzing them I started firing
off emails to colleagues around the
world who are doing the same sort of
thing um and we set up a Wiki where we
could all post our results and critique
them and uh and people that are in uh
competing groups work together kind of
Around the Clock we had some people in
Arizona people in the UK people in Hong
Kong so for a period of a couple weeks
we were kind of working 16-hour days and
when you fell asleep you knew that when
you woke up in the morning the research
would be Advanced another eight hours um
and and pretty quickly came to grips
with uh the timeline of this thing um
that kind of Open Access mentality
flowed right through to the publication
in nature so nature published this even
though we'd already had some press
